blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: It contradicts itself. It changes tone mid-sentence. One moment you're angry. The next you're tender. The next you're ashamed.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: You tell it differently each time. The coffee shop chair that creaks. The unread thread on your phone. The groceries they brought. The lies they told. The way they stayed. The way they left. All of it true. All of it incomplete.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: And weirdly—there's relief in that. Like you stopped forcing it to be pretty. Like you finally let it be what it is: messy, unresolved, real.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: People don't know what to do with it. They want a verdict. You can't give them one.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: Your phone buzzes. The unread thread is still there. You don't check it. You don't delete it. You just let it sit there, like a question you're not ready to answer.

blocks.speaker: brain
blocks.text: It's not resolved. It's real. And that's enough.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: You choose your words like you're handling glass.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: You don't turn the past into a weapon. You don't make anyone the monster of the story. You don't mention the unread thread. You don't mention the coffee shop chair that creaks. You don't mention the groceries. You don't mention the lies.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: It's careful. It's kind. It also leaves you holding a lot by yourself.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: Later, alone, you check your phone. The thread is still there. Unread. You don't open it. You just let it sit there, like a wound you're protecting.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: Your friends say you're too nice. You don't correct them. You don't say: it's not nice. It's protection. And protection is lonely.

blocks.speaker: brain
blocks.text: Protection is love. Protection is loneliness. You hold both at once.

choices.label: Restart with a different first memory.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: After, you can't keep the story in one piece.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: You remember flashes. The coffee shop chair that creaks. The unread thread on your phone. The groceries they brought. The lies they told. The kindness. The absence. The way they held their phone. The way they tapped their fingers. The way they said your name.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: You remember tones. The way their voice sounded when they were lying. The way it sounded when they weren't.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: You remember the feeling of your own pulse. Racing. Slowing. Stopping.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: The facts are there somewhere, but every time you reach, your hand comes back empty. The story fragments. The pieces don't fit.

blocks.speaker: narrator
blocks.text: Your phone buzzes. You don't check it. You can't. You don't remember what you're avoiding. You just know you're avoiding it.

blocks.speaker: brain
blocks.text: Your mind protected you the only way it knew how. By forgetting. By fragmenting. By making the story impossible to tell.
